reviews.review:
This game has been on my list for a while, so I decided to bite the bullet and get this old gem, and I can say that although it is a great and subversive piece that was zip-tied to the Orange Box and a pleasant surprise for all, it's sequel is a better version of the mechanics and style this game tried (and did) accomplish, but it doesn't devalue the experience I had with it.

One thing I think this game excels at over the continuation was the impending loneliness. Now that might be obvious considering the only prominent voice work is of Ellen McLain (including the turrets) and the cast of characters is relatively higher than this game, but I feel its design in both level and story makes it higher in this regard. 

Now I have played Portal 2 a handful of times, and this only for the first time, even with knowing the outcome of the game, I suspended my belief and played it like a kid who just got the Orange Box and found this interesting Portal game inside the bundle, and man was it a melancholic void. I think the level design is the key factor that created that added level of isolation, from these pristine white walls and polished cubes, having a very up-kept feeling with the subtle yet powerful contrast of broken or dirty areas like the 'weird goo'. It was like looking into a cubist painting and seeing a small leak of an unsightly faded green seeping from behind the painting, that sense of unease really heightened the subnormal atmosphere of the place. This was also strengthened when stumbling upon the Ratman dens, which really started to tip the scales in the uncanny nature of the facility.

Now compare that to Portal 2, where the old test track is now run over with greenery and faint birds can be heard. It is completely obvious this place was abandoned and has no upkeep whatsoever. The answer stares you in the face. Now that isn't bad, since it is building upon the previously established story and themes from its predecessor whilst adding new content to create a new but still continuous experience (AKA The Perfect Sequel), but I love the drip-feed in Portal 1 that is the true nature of Aperture Laboratories being this husk of a facility overrun by a sentient, omnipresent and rebellious robot regulator, and that couldn't have been present in the latter half of the franchise.

Now what I really have trouble with is a specific way that tests are dealt with compared to how they deal with their tests in Portal 2. If you enter the Developer Commentary section of Portal 1 and listen to what they say, all of their design choices make complete sense and were felt throughout the game, such as the introduction of new mechanics and the clever ways they can train your mind to find the solutions through the use of context clues, Ratman's scribblings or previously learned game mechanics. The problem I have with the tests is them having pivotal test solving moments in a style I'd like to call "Rehearsal/Reaction Testing", which is a good fit for a puzzle platformer game, but some sections seem to feel harder on new players. Let me explain.

I understand that being a God at puzzles but no proficiency at platforming or vice versa is not what the game is trying to accomplish. It is supposed to make you improve in both fields, but it feels that the game assumes you have a certain level of reaction that some players might not actually have before playing this game. Valve has done an excellent job on teaching new players mechanics and introducing/debunking concepts the player stumbles upon by just doing the right footwork, but still let's the players actually figure things out by themselves with all the valid information given, but platforming can be done in a similar fashion. They still have introduced flinging techniques well, but it felt too little too late for me, as even in some areas I was struggling to piece together the information I have already gathered from playing Portal 2, its community mods and the Perpetual Testing Initiative, among other things. They only really get introduced halfway through the game and sometimes I felt like when I did some of my flings, it was completely different to how it was supposed to be completed, which I either did it the deliberate way or the puzzle is more open ended, which is good, but if an intermediate player like me can't figure out what is the desired and purposeful solution, I'm sure the new players couldn't even try to find the shoddy workarounds that I did, let alone the actual intended path.

Those moments only took up around 5% of my actual experience, and were less game breaking then I might let on, but I still find it a valid point of criticism (which had already been worked on wayyyyyyyy before even started thinking to play this) for Portal 1.

The only other real critique I can say is that the graphics haven't aged well, but that has nothing to do with Valve, that's just the cruel passage that is time. Apart from those, I really have nothing else to say negatively about this game. Its story is intriguing whilst it expands the canonical Valve Universe, the gameplay is finely tuned to create an incredibly unique puzzle experience and has cemented the franchise as the Puzzle Platforming juggernaut that is so truly deserves.

Thanks Valve :D

El primer Portal es un videojuego de puzles en toda la regla, no tiene una historia compleja ni cinematicas que hagan tediosa tu inicio en tu aventura. Los acertijos son en algunas casos bastante complicados pero no son para nada rebuscados, por lo que podras superarlos con la suficiente inteligencia.
Ademas el juego cuenta con algunas peque√±as bromas sutiles que haran la travesia mas dinamica y divertida

This was a triumph.
I'm making a note here: HUGE SUCCESS.
It's hard to overstate my satisfaction.
Aperture Science
We do what we must
because we can.
For the good of all of us.
Except the ones who are dead.

But there's no sense crying over every mistake.
You just keep on trying till you run out of cake.
And the Science gets done.
And you make a neat gun.
For the people who are still alive.

I'm not even angry.
I'm being so sincere right now.
Even though you broke my heart.
And killed me.
And tore me to pieces.
And threw every piece into a fire.
As they burned it hurt because I was so happy for you!
Now these points of data make a beautiful line.
And we're out of beta.
We're releasing on time.
So I'm GLaD. I got burned.
Think of all the things we learned
for the people who are
still alive.

Go ahead and leave me.
I think I prefer to stay inside.
Maybe you'll find someone else to help you.
Maybe Black Mesa...
THAT WAS A JOKE.
HAHA. FAT CHANCE.
Anyway, this cake is great.
It's so delicious and moist.
Look at me still talking
when there's Science to do.
When I look out there, it makes me GLaD I'm not you.
I've experiments to run.
There is research to be done.
On the people who are still alive.
And believe me I am still alive.
I'm doing Science and I'm still alive.
I feel FANTASTIC and I'm still alive.

While you're dying I'll be still alive.

And when you're dead I will be still alive.

STILL ALIVE

Still alive
I know this game has been out for ages but now that I have played it I definitely get the draw. It is a wonderful logic and physics game that will have your heart pumping towards the end.
Very fun game, you can solve puzzles using portals and the "portal gun" in the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, and there is an AI named GlaDOS who is the owner of Aperture Science
Game's pretty good, its a classic, and portal 2 is even nicer! I recomend getting the portal bundle, get both games for a low price, no more than 20$ depending on your region
I mean. This game is a classic. How could you not find zipping in portals fun. The puzzles were pretty good, and it is improved with the engaging story and atmosphere.
